results.title: Urbanites Flock to Atlantic Canada as Pandemic Blunts Cities’ Appeal
results.abstract: As housing prices soar in big cities, the country’s eastern provinces are experiencing a surge in migration. Newcomers are being welcomed, but some locals are wary.

multimedia.caption: Houses along the coastline in Bonavista, Newfoundland. Young professionals from across Canada are pouring in to the region.
multimedia.copyright: Chris Donovan for The New York Times

results.title: Migrants Say Belarusians Took Them to E.U. Border and Supplied Wire Cutters
results.abstract: Iraqi Kurds and other migrants said they were fleeing despair at home, but Belarus encouraged them, offering visas and helping them get to the border.
results.byline: By Jane Arraf and Elian Peltier
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Kamyar and Sarhang, second and third from left, were joined by friends as they picked up their visas for Belarus on Thursday at a travel agency in Sulaimaniya, Iraq.
multimedia.copyright: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

results.title: For Meghan, an Image Rendered in a U.K.-U.S. Split Screen
results.abstract: She has re-emerged in America as a formidable A-list celebrity and social activist. In Britain, however, Meghan remains a polarizing figure.

multimedia.caption: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, at a gala for veterans in New York on Wednesday.

results.title: From ‘Alive Among the Dead,’ to ‘Dead Among the Living’
results.abstract: The trauma of the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris was highlighted in testimony by survivors and others at a trial of 20 men accused of involvement.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A memorial in 2015 for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris.
multimedia.copyright: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

results.title: India Wants to Send Wheat to Ease Afghan Hunger Crisis. Pakistan Has Yet to OK Transit.
results.abstract: Indian officials say Islamabad is dragging its feet on a request of transit for 50,000 tons of wheat to Afghanistan, where nine million people are on the brink of starvation.

multimedia.caption: Loading grain onto a truck in February in Amritsar, in the northwestern Indian state of Punjab, near the border with Pakistan.
multimedia.copyright: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times

results.title: Dictator’s Son Says Daughter of Duterte Will Back Him in Philippine Election
results.abstract: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who hopes to succeed Rodrigo Duterte as president, said Sara Duterte would effectively be his running mate.
results.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Jason Gutierrez
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the former dictator of the Philippines, after officially entering the presidential race last month.
multimedia.copyright: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Deep Underground, a Chinese Miner Discovered Poetry in the Toil
results.abstract: Chen Nianxi has risen to fame as a “migrant worker poet,” adding the voice of China’s often-invisible laborers to the cultural conversation.

multimedia.caption: Chen Nianxi, a miner who became a poet, in a scene from the documentary film “Iron Moon.”

results.title: Sudanese Security Forces Fire on Protesters as Military Tightens Grip
results.abstract: At least five people were killed and several wounded as the police fired bullets and tear gas at demonstrators in Sudan’s capital, two days after the army chief signed a contentious decree.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: Protesters in Port Sudan marched on Saturday against the government of  Lt. Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, who has tightened his grip on Sudan since ousting the civilian prime minister.

results.title: Migrant Crisis in Belarus Tests Putin’s Uneasy Alliance With Lukashenko
results.abstract: Last year Vladimir V. Putin helped save Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s Belarusian regime. But Russia now has an ever-more-erratic ally and risks entanglement in a dangerous crisis.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in September.

results.title: In Border Crisis, Europe’s Unsavory Migration Deals Come Home
results.abstract: Europe has long paid other nations to keep refugees away from its borders. Now, Belarus wants something, too, and has brought migrants right to Europe’s door to get it.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: A satellite image of migrants gathering at the Belarus-Poland border on Wednesday.

results.title: Ethiopian Civil War Sparks Rancorous Debate Over Immigration to Israel
results.abstract: Thousands of relatives of the remnants of Ethiopian Jewry are waiting to be airlifted to Israel. For now, the Israeli government sees no urgency.

multimedia.caption: Ethiopian immigrants arriving last year in Tel Aviv. Israel has rescued thousands of Jewish Ethiopians and their families, but questions about the eligibility of new immigrants has stirred debate.

results.title: In France, Kamala Harris Searches for Role on Global Stage
results.abstract: The vice president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France, skirting recent U.S.-French tensions, and immersed herself in issues like Libya and cybersecurity.
results.byline: By Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Vice President Kamala Harris in Paris on Friday.

results.title: Myanmar Court Sentences American Journalist to 11 Years
results.abstract: Danny Fenster was given the toughest possible sentence on three charges, in a signal that the country’s military rulers would not bow to international pressure.

multimedia.caption: Danny Fenster at work in Louisiana, in an undated photograph provided by his family.
multimedia.copyright: Agence France-Presse, via Fenster Family/Afp Via Getty Images

results.title: For Some South Africans, de Klerk Missed Chances for True Reconciliation
results.abstract: The last white president of South Africa helped bring an end to the apartheid regime, but for many citizens, he never went far enough to disavow it. He left a video apologizing.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: F.W. de Klerk, the former president of South Africa, released a posthumous video message. “I without qualification apologize for the pain and hurt and the indignity and the damage that apartheid has done to Black, brown and Indians in South Africa.”
multimedia.copyright: F. W. de Klerk Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
results.abstract: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
results.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Fleeing heavy bombardment in Baghuz, Syria — the Islamic State’s last holdout — on March 18, 2019.

results.title: Portugal bars companies from contacting employees off hours and requires other protections for remote work.
results.abstract: A new law, passed on Friday and in effect this weekend, is one of the world’s boldest efforts to regulate the remote work that the pandemic forced on many in the industrialized world.

multimedia.caption: Commuters at a subway station in Lisbon last week.

results.title: As Hackers Take Down Newfoundland’s Health Care System, Silence Descends
results.abstract: The province has said little about a cyberattack that delayed or canceled medical procedures and leaked personal information.

multimedia.caption: The residents of Bonavista, like everyone in Newfoundland and Labrador, are experiencing health care disruptions.
multimedia.copyright: Chris Donovan for The New York Times

results.title: Oklahoma’s governor puts an opponent of vaccine mandates in charge of the National Guard.
results.abstract: The governor, Kevin Stitt, is one of a number of Republican state officials across the country who has been fighting against President Biden’s vaccine mandates.

multimedia.caption: Members of the Oklahoma National Guard were deployed to the U.S. Capitol in Washington in January.

results.title: 2 Ivory Smugglers Captured in International Operation, U.S. Says
results.abstract: The men were captured by relying on DNA sampling from a previously seized ivory haul, which helped experts pinpoint the location of poached elephants.

multimedia.caption: Some of the $3.5 million worth of ivory and rhino horn seized in the operation.

results.title: Threats and troop movements ramp up a European stalemate with Cold War echoes.
results.abstract: On both sides of the Belarus-Poland border, hyperbole and military exercises have raised fears of an armed conflict in Europe.

multimedia.caption: An image from video released by Belarus’s Defense Ministry on Friday showing what it said were Russian paratroopers during joint military exercises near the border with Poland.
multimedia.copyright: Belarusian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press

results.title: California broadens access to Covid booster shots.
results.abstract: Officials are seeking to avert a winter surge; last year, so many Covid patients died that officials were forced to deploy mobile morgues.
results.byline: By John Yoon and Jill Cowan

multimedia.caption: A pharmacist administering a booster shot at a Safeway in San Rafael, Calif., last month. California’s new policy allows all adults in the state to receive booster shots.

results.title: ‘Be Nice to Tourists’: New York’s Arts Scene Needs International Visitors
results.abstract: The United States now allows vaccinated international travelers into the country. It’s welcome news for arts institutions that lost revenue and cut jobs during the pandemic.

multimedia.caption: About 70 percent of the tickets at the TKTS booth in Times Square are bought by tourists and roughly half of those sales are to foreign travelers.
multimedia.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

results.title: Julian Assange to Wed in Prison in Britain
results.abstract: The WikiLeaks founder, who is battling extradition to the United States on espionage charges, has been granted permission to marry Stella Moris in the London prison where he has been held since 2019.

multimedia.caption: Stella Moris with her children Gabriel, left, and Max in June outside Belmarsh Prison in London after a visit with Julian Assange, her partner and their father.
multimedia.copyright: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press

results.title: Germany will again offer free Covid tests to all adults.
results.abstract: Officials hope that identifying infections earlier can help stop a recent surge in cases.

multimedia.caption: Costumed revelers celebrating at carnival festivities in Cologne, Germany, on Thursday.

results.title: The Show Goes On, Even After China Tried to Shut It Down
results.abstract: An Italian city rejected a request from the Chinese Embassy in Rome to cancel an exhibition by Badiucao, an artist who has been described as the Chinese Banksy.

multimedia.caption: Badiucao in front of one of his works, “Carrie Lam,” a portrait of Hong Kong’s chief executive, at Santa Giulia Museum in Brescia, Italy.
multimedia.copyright: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

results.title: Many migrants in Belarus flew there. Airlines on Friday moved to end that practice.
results.abstract: Some airlines have agreed to stop taking Iraqi, Syrian and Yemeni citizens to Minsk, which the E.U. hopes will stem the flow of migrants to the bloc’s borders.
results.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Carlotta Gall
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: A Turkish Airlines plane taking off from Istanbul in 2019.

results.title: Aiming for ‘zero Covid,’ China focuses on frozen food, children’s clothes and, soon, the Olympics.
results.abstract: The Communist Party is making broad efforts to stamp out the disease entirely, but the measures come with costs.
results.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

multimedia.caption: Lining up for coronavirus testing amid the emergence of local cases in Liaoning Province, China, this week.

results.title: How Does This End?
results.abstract: Thinking about Covid and normalcy.

multimedia.caption: Cable car riders in San Francisco.

results.title: The Netherlands imposes a partial lockdown for all, as European cases and deaths rise.
results.abstract: The Dutch lockdown does not single out those who are unvaccinated. The country is experiencing rising case numbers amid a fourth wave of infections.

multimedia.caption: Shoppers wearing face masks in Amsterdam this month.

results.title: Hong Kong Broadcaster’s Swift Turn From Maverick Voice to Official Mouthpiece
results.abstract: RTHK has often set the news agenda with its aggressive coverage of the city. But a Beijing clampdown has changed that, with pro-China coverage filling the void.

multimedia.caption: The set of the television show “Headliner” at Radio Television Hong Kong last year. RTHK executives suspended the show after the Hong Kong police complained about an episode that mocked the force.
multimedia.copyright: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

results.title: Migration and Experimentation: What Led to Australia’s Coffee Culture
results.abstract: When Italian migrants arrived after World War II, they helped develop a coffee scene that many now regard as the best in the world.

multimedia.caption: Seven Seeds, in Melbourne.
multimedia.copyright: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times

results.title: Your Friday Briefing
results.abstract: Migrants in peril at Belarus-Poland border.

multimedia.caption: Migrants in the Grodno region of Belarus, near the Polish border.

results.title: Migrants in Peril, and Raw Emotions, in a Volatile European Border Standoff
results.abstract: A confrontation over migrants between Belarus and Poland is growing more volatile, as nationalist fervor rises in both countries and a humanitarian disaster looms.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Migrants at the Poland-Belarus border, early Thursday.
multimedia.copyright: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times

results.title: The clash over the Belarus-Poland border crisis spills into the U.N. Security Council.
results.abstract: The United States joined several countries in a statement condemning Belarus, but the Russian envoy dismissed their criticism as politically motivated hypocrisy.

multimedia.caption: The Russian deputy ambassador to the United Nations, Dmitry Polyanskiy, during a Security Council session in September. He rejected criticism of Belarus, a Russian ally.

results.title: Who Is Aleksandr G. Lukashenko? Here’s What You Need to Know.
results.abstract: A migrant crisis on the border with Poland has put the Belarusian president at the center of a clash roiling Europe.
results.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Andrew Higgins
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus during a visit to Moscow in September. The mercurial leader has a long history of defying the West.

results.title: Your Friday Briefing
results.abstract: China’s communists elevate Xi’s status.

multimedia.caption: China’s elites placed Xi Jinping, left, among the country’s era-defining leaders.
